Daniel and Jeff, please note that the rules cited by Daniel in a couple c=
ases are not exactly what my implementation of NEAT does (and since JNEAT i=
s based on my own I assume it follows the same rules mine).  Of course the =
code is a bit complicated and figuring out what it does is difficult to do =
quickly.  In particular here are corrections for b and c:

(b) Species are =
not killed off if their average fitness falls below a certain level.  Rathe=
r, there is a rule that, if turned on, would kill off a species if its maxi=
mum fitness has not improved in some number of generations.  That is a way =
to dump stagnant species.

(c) "Stolen babies" is almost never used in any =
experiment that I have seen published or published myself, so it isn't real=
ly an important mechanism.  However, it is a way to increase greediness.  A=
s Daniel rightly infers, it doesn't steal actual genetic code from one spec=
ies, but rather it steals the *right* to reproduce from the worse species a=
nd redistributes that right to the better ones.  So sort of Robin Hood in r=
everse (steal from the poor to help the rich).  

In terms of "weighting th=
e number of offspring produced towards the stronger species," that is corre=
ct, but that is just a property of fitness sharing, which NEAT uses.  

In =
general, the most important selection mechanism in NEAT is in fact fitness =
sharing, which makes it difficult for good species to take over the entire =
population because individuals must share the fitness of their species.  So=
 as a species gets bigger, the fitness of everyone within it drops.  I woul=
d consider fitness sharing essential to NEAT's "identity."

However, all fi=
tness sharing does is adjust the fitnesses of everyone in the population.  =
So after that, there is still a need to decide how many offpspring individu=
als get.  It is at this point that versions of NEAT may diverge and I do no=
t have a strong opinion because I do not consider the choice essential to N=
EAT's identity.

In my own implementations, first, offspring numbers are as=
signed on a per-species basis (proportionally to *adjusted* fitness after f=
itness sharing) and then they are assigned within to species to individuals=
.  My version of NEAT usually uses truncation selection within species.  So=
 it just cuts out the bottom n% of the species from being eligible to repro=
duce and the rest get to reproduce.  (rtNEAT is different of course since i=
t only produces one at a time - it probabilistic).  The remaining individua=
ls are selected as parents randomly.

Perhaps most appealing for me about t=
his approach is the idea that each species can be treated as its own little=
 mini-population in which whatever selection scheme you choose is implement=
ed.  I think it makes conceptual sense to think of a species as a populatio=
n because *within* a species one wants the same kind of healthy phenomena t=
o happen that one wants in a regular GA with a full population.

Of course,=
 you could alternatively choose roulette wheel selection within species (af=
ter adjusting fitness for fitness sharing) or something else.  That choice =
is not that important, and I have tried a number of schemes and found that,=
 at least with NEAT, it makes limited difference which one is chosen.  But =
the fitness sharing is still key.

So Jeff, there is no simple to answer to=
 "what kind of selection scheme does NEAT use" because it is a multi-level =
scheme that first acts at the level of speciation and then at the level of =
individuals within species.  So no one blanket terms really covers the whol=
e thing.  To distill it to a short phrase, perhaps we could say it uses "fi=
tness sharing and any other scheme after fitness-sharing."

ken

   


--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, Daniel Tuohy <danielr2e@...> wrote:
>
> I'm helpin=
g with the overhaul of JNeat.  I hadn't even looked at selection,
> but now=
 that I do it seems very strange.  Perhaps Ken could explain what is
> goin=
g on here.
> 
> It looks like all the selection pressure comes from:
> 
>  =
(a) Elitism within species ("champions" are automatically cloned into the
>=
 subsequent generation)
>  (b) Killing off species when their average fitne=
ss falls below a certain
> threshhold
>  (c) Weighting the number of offspr=
ing produced towards the stronger
> species.  (In the code the metaphor of =
"stealing babies" from weaker species
> is used, although this doesn't seem=
 quite right to me.  Surely if a species
> were to "steal a baby", it would=
 retain the genetic material of it's
> original species?)
> 
> With all tha=
t said, you're question is on the mathematical function that
> describes se=
lection pressure relative to fitness, right?  Unfortunately, I'm
> finding =
it very difficult to infer that from the above mechanisms.  I bet
> Ken kno=
ws :)
> 
> Daniel
>

...> wrote:
> 
> >
> >
> > Hello all-
> >

s been answered before.
> >

kind of selection does NEAT use?
> > I know the fitness is affected by spec=
iation, but at the core is it still
> > fitness proportional, or tournament=
?
> >
> > In other words, do I need to be doing things like 2^fitness to ma=
gnify
> > small
> > improvements in fitness to help these small improvement=
s get selected for,
> > or does that not matter?
